learning_outcomes.description: identify, analyse and integrate relevant industry legislation, codes and standards,
identify, analyse and integrate appropriate structural, construction and environmental strategies,
collaboratively produce a schematic design proposal,
individually produce a design development report, and
collaboratively produce a set of construction drawings.

assessments.due_date:
Submission via Blackboard 20/08/2025 4:00 pm

Presentation & Discussion in class 20/08/2025
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

Students work in a small group to resolve and develop a provided schematic design proposal, including the selection of structural materials and set outs, service strategies and envelope systems and materials based on environmental performance requirement and the requirements of the National Construction Code. Groups must also prepare and submit weekly meeting minutes to track project progress and guide engagement with tutors. The collected meeting minutes are to be submitted with Assignment 1. Group peer assessment tools (BuddyCheck) will provide formative feedback on group performance in Assignment 1 that modifies individual student marks.

Group work note: Group work plays a significant part of BLDG3220, and has been incorporated into the subject to help prepare you for working in architectural practice should you decide to take a year out between the Bachelor and Masters courses. Exercises in week 1 of semester will help to form groups and to make clear agreements or contracts between group members about how to communicate, how to share resources, how to give feedback and advice to other group members and the consequences for any group member for not following the group agreement. Group work can be difficult, particularly as the stresses of semester mount and assessment items for other subjects are due. If you find that your group is not functioning effectively please contact the course co-ordinator for support.

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI and/or MT: his assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

In Assignment 2 students continue to work with their group from Assignment 1 to further resolve the schematic design proposal, this time at a finer level of detail. Assignment 2 is graded individually, but students continue to work in alignment with the rest of their group , to resolve construction details at 1:20, 1:10 or 1:5 in a way that supports and reinforces the architectural ideas that were presented in Assignment 1. A Detail Development template will be provided as a guide. Formative feedback will be provided in tutorials on work-in-progress and an assignment Q+A session in Week 8. 

Groups must also prepare and submit weekly meeting minutes to track project progress and guide engagement with tutors. The collected meeting minutes are to be submitted with Assignment 2. Group peer assessment tools (BuddyCheck) will provide formative feedback on group performance in Assignment 2 that does not modify individual student marks.

Group work note: Group work plays a significant part of BLDG3220, and has been incorporated into the subject to help prepare you for working in architectural practice should you decide to take a year out between the Bachelor and Masters courses. Exercises in week 1 of semester will help to form groups and to make clear agreements or contracts between group members about how to communicate, how to share resources, how to give feedback and advice to other group members and the consequences for any group member for not following the group agreement. Group work can be difficult, particularly as the stresses of semester mount and assessment items for other subjects are due. Even though this assignment is individual work, the dynamics of your group may impact on your productivity. If you find that your group is not functioning effectively please contact the course co-ordinator for support.

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI and/or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

In Assignment 3 students return to working collaboratively with their group from assignments 1 and 2 to produce a set of coordinated and coherent construction drawings for the design they have developed and refined in Assignments 1 and 2.

Groups must also prepare and submit weekly meeting minutes to track project progress and guide engagement with tutors. The collected meeting minutes are to be submitted with Assignment 3. Group peer assessment tools (BuddyCheck) will provide summative feedback on group performance in Assignment 3 that modifies individual student marks.

Group work plays a significant part of BLDG3220, and has been incorporated into the subject to help prepare you for working in architectural practice should you decide to take a year out between the Bachelor and Masters courses. Exercises in week 1 of semester will help to form groups and to make clear agreements or contracts between group members about how to communicate, how to share resources, how to give feedback and advice to other group members and the consequences for any group member for not following the group agreement. Group work can be difficult, particularly as the stresses of semester mount and assessment items for other subjects are due. If you find that your group is not functioning effectively please contact the course co-ordinator for support.

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI and/or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Workshop

Week 1 - Course Introduction, team formation and schematic design selection

Week 2 - Structural, servicing and environmental strategies 1

Week 3 - Structural, servicing and environmental strategies 2

Week 4 - Assignment 1 submission and review

Week 5 - Construction processes and staging, practice detail selection

Week 6 - Practice detail development

Week 7 - Detail development 1

Week 8 - Detail development 2

Week 9 - Assignment 2 submission and briefing for Assignment 3

Week 10 - Construction Documentation 1

Week 11 - Construction Documentation 2

Week 12 - Construction Documentation 3

Week 13 - Design Week - no class this week

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Workshop Week 1 - Course Introduction, team formation and schematic design selection Week 2 - Structural, servicing and environmental strategies 1 Week 3 - Structural, servicing and environmental strategies 2 Week 4 - Assignment 1 submission and review Week 5 - Construction processes and staging, practice detail selection Week 6 - Practice detail development Week 7 - Detail development 1 Week 8 - Detail development 2 Week 9 - Assignment 2 submission and briefing for Assignment 3 Week 10 - Construction Documentation 1 Week 11 - Construction Documentation 2 Week 12 - Construction Documentation 3 Week 13 - Design Week - no class this week

learning_activities.topic:
Field trips

Weekly in-class workshops will be supported by site visits to view and examine buildings under construction and completed buildings. Currently three site visits are being planned:

  • the Advanced Engineering Building (concrete framed, window wall building),
  • the Andrew N Liveris Building (concrete framed curtain wall building),
  • 25 King Street, Fortitude Valley (mass timber framed curtain wall building)

Dates for site visits will be confirmed as soon as possible. Site visits will be planned for Thursday afternoons.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
